member.name: T:Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.ContainerOpenSSLCertificateFile
member.summary: Represents an OpenSSL public certificate in the container file system. Must be PEM encoded. An OpenSSL compatible symlink pointing to the destination file will be created in the same container folder as the certificate file named [subject hash].[n], where [n] is a sequence number that increases for each certificate in a target folder with the same subject hash.

member.param: The directory path to enumerate files from.
The search pattern to control the items matched. Defaults to *.
The search options to control the items matched. Defaults to SearchOption.TopDirectoryOnly.
An optional function to update each before returning it. This can be used to set additional properties like Owner, Group, or Mode.
member.exception: Thrown when the specified path does not exist.

member.name: T:Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.ContainerFileSystemCallbackAnnotation
member.summary: Represents a callback annotation that specifies files and folders that should be created or updated in a container.

member.name: P:Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.ContainerFileSystemCallbackAnnotation.DestinationPath
member.summary: The (absolute) base path to create the new file (and any parent directories) in the container. This path should already exist in the container.

member.name: P:Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.ContainerFileSystemCallbackAnnotation.DefaultOwner
member.summary: The UID of the default owner for files/directories to be created or updated in the container. The UID defaults to 0 for root if null.

member.name: P:Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.ContainerFileSystemCallbackAnnotation.DefaultGroup
member.summary: The GID of the default group for files/directories to be created or updated in the container. The GID defaults to 0 for root if null.

member.name: P:Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.ContainerFileSystemCallbackAnnotation.Umask
member.summary: The umask to apply to files or folders without an explicit mode permission. If set to null, a default umask value of 0022 (octal) will be used. The umask takes away permissions from the default permission set (rather than granting them).
member.remarks: The umask is a bitmask that determines the default permissions for newly created files and directories. The umask value is subtracted (bitwise masked) from the maximum possible default permissions to determine the final permissions. For directories, the umask is subtracted from 0777 (rwxrwxrwx) to get the final permissions and for files it is subtracted from 0666 (rw-rw-rw-). For a umask of 0022, this gives a default folder permission of 0755 (rwxr-xr-x) and a default file permission of 0644 (rw-r--r--).

member.name: P:Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.ContainerFileSystemCallbackAnnotation.Callback
member.summary: The callback to be executed when the container is created. Should return a tree of entries to create (or update) in the container.

member.name: T:Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.ContainerLifetime
member.summary: Lifetime modes for container resources.

member.name: F:Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.ContainerLifetime.Session
member.summary: Create the resource when the app host process starts and dispose of it when the app host process shuts down.

member.name: F:Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.ContainerLifetime.Persistent
member.summary: Attempt to re-use a previously created resource (based on the container name) if one exists. Do not destroy the container on app host process shutdown.
member.remarks:
In the event that a container with the given name does not exist, a new container will always be created based on the current configuration.
When an existing container IS found, Aspire MAY re-use it based on the following criteria:
If the container WAS NOT originally created by Aspire, the existing container will be re-used.
If the container WAS originally created by Aspire, and the configuration DOES match the existing container, the existing container will be re-used.
If the container WAS originally created by Aspire, and the configuration DOES NOT match the existing container, the existing container will be stopped and a new container created in order to apply the updated configuration.

The state of the command.
The display name visible in UI for the command.
Optional description of the command, to be shown in the UI. Could be used as a tooltip. May be localized.
Optional parameter that configures the command in some way. Clients must return any value provided by the server when invoking the command.

The icon variant.
A flag indicating whether the command is highlighted in the UI.

member.name: T:Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.ExecutableResource
member.summary: A resource that represents a specified executable process.
member.remarks:
You can run any executable command using its full path. As a security feature, Aspire doesn't run executable unless the command is located in a path listed in the PATH environment variable.
To run an executable file that's in the current directory, specify the full path or use the relative path ./ to represent the current directory.

member.name: T:Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IAspireStore
member.summary: Represents a store for managing files in the Aspire hosting environment that can be reused across runs.
member.remarks:
The store is created in the ./obj folder of the Application Host. If the ASPIRE__STORE__PATH environment variable is set this will be used instead.
The store is specific to a instance such that each application can't conflict with others. A .aspire prefix is also used to ensure that the folder can be deleted without impacting unrelated files.

member.name: P:Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IAspireStore.BasePath
member.summary: Gets the base path of this store.

member.summary: Gets a deterministic file path that is a copy of the content from the provided stream. The resulting file name will depend on the content of the stream.
member.param: A file name to base the result on.
A stream containing the content.
member.returns: A deterministic file path with the same content as the provided stream.

member.name: T:Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.GenerateParameterDefault
member.summary: Represents that a default value should be generated.
member.remarks:
The recommended minimum bits of entropy for a generated password is 128 bits.
The general calculation of bits of entropy is:
log base 2 (numberPossibleOutputs)
This generator uses 23 upper case, 23 lower case (excludes i,l,o,I,L,O to prevent confusion), 10 numeric, and 11 special characters. So a total of 67 possible characters.
When all character sets are enabled, the number of possible outputs is (67 ^ length). The minimum password length for 128 bits of entropy is 22 characters: log base 2 (67 ^ 22).
When character sets are disabled, it lowers the number of possible outputs and thus the bits of entropy.
Using MinLower, MinUpper, MinNumeric, and MinSpecial also lowers the number of possible outputs and thus the bits of entropy.
A generalized lower-bound formula for the number of possible outputs is to consider a string of the form:
{nonRequiredCharacters}{requiredCharacters}
let a = MinLower, b = MinUpper, c = MinNumeric, d = MinSpecial let x = length - (a + b + c + d)
nonRequiredPossibilities = 67^x requiredPossibilities = 23^a * 23^b * 10^c * 11^d * (a + b + c + d)! / (a! * b! * c! * d!)
lower-bound of total possibilities = nonRequiredPossibilities * requiredPossibilities
Putting it all together, the lower-bound bits of entropy calculation is:
log base 2 [67^x * 23^a * 23^b * 10^c * 11^d * (a + b + c + d)! / (a! * b! * c! * d!)]

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.ResourceCommandService.ExecuteCommandAsync(System.String,System.String,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Execute a command for the specified resource.

remarks.para: A resource id can be either the unique id of the resource or the displayed resource name.

Projects, executables and containers typically have a unique id that combines the display name and a unique suffix. For example, a resource named cache could have a resource id of cache-abcdwxyz. This id is used to uniquely identify the resource in the app host.

The resource name can be also be used to retrieve the resource state, but it must be unique. If there are multiple resources with the same name, then this method will not return a match. For example, if a resource named cache has multiple replicas, then specifing cache won't return a match.

member.param: The resource id. This id can either exactly match the unique id of the resource or the displayed resource name if the resource name doesn't have duplicates (i.e. replicas).
The command name.
The cancellation token.
member.returns: The indicates command success or failure.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.ResourceCommandService.ExecuteCommandAsync(Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResource,System.String,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Execute a command for the specified resource.
member.param: The resource. If the resource has multiple instances, such as replicas, then the command will be executed for each instance.
The command name.
The cancellation token.
member.returns: The indicates command success or failure.

member.summary: Processes environment variable values for the specified resource within the given execution context.

The logger used to log any information or errors during the environment variables processing.
The optional container host name associated with the resource being processed.
A cancellation token to observe during the asynchronous operation.
member.returns: A task that represents the asynchronous operation.

remarks.para: This method returns a task that will complete with the resource is healthy. A resource without annotations will be considered healthy once it reaches a state.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.ResourceNotificationService.TryGetCurrentState(System.String,Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.ResourceEvent@)
member.summary: Attempts to retrieve the current state of a resource by resourceId.

remarks.para: A resource id can be either the unique id of the resource or the displayed resource name.

Projects, executables and containers typically have a unique id that combines the display name and a unique suffix. For example, a resource named cache could have a resource id of cache-abcdwxyz. This id is used to uniquely identify the resource in the app host.

The resource name can be also be used to retrieve the resource state, but it must be unique. If there are multiple resources with the same name, then this method will not return a match. For example, if a resource named cache has multiple replicas, then specifing cache won't return a match.

member.param: The resource id. This id can either exactly match the unique id of the resource or the displayed resource name if the resource name doesn't have duplicates (i.e. replicas).
When this method returns, contains the for the specified resource id, if found; otherwise, .
member.returns: if specified resource id was found; otherwise, .

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.ContainerResourceBuilderExtensions.WithVolume``1(Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResourceBuilder{``0},System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Adds a volume to a container resource.
member.param: The resource builder.
The name of the volume.
The target path where the volume is mounted in the container.
A flag that indicates if the volume should be mounted as read-only.

remarks.para: Volumes are used to persist file-based data generated by and used by the container. They are managed by the container runtime and can be shared among multiple containers. They are not shared with the host's file-system. To mount files from the host inside the container, call .

If a value for the of the volume is not provided, the volume is created as an "anonymous volume" and will be given a random name by the container runtime. To share a volume between multiple containers, specify the same .
The path specifies the path the volume will be mounted inside the container's file system.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.ContainerResourceBuilderExtensions.WithVolume``1(Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResourceBuilder{``0},System.String)
member.summary: Adds an anonymous volume to a container resource.
member.param: The resource builder.
The target path where the volume is mounted in the container.

remarks.para: Volumes are used to persist file-based data generated by and used by the container. They are managed by the container runtime and can be shared among multiple containers. They are not shared with the host's file-system. To mount files from the host inside the container, call .
This overload will create an "anonymous volume" and will be given a random name by the container runtime. To share a volume between multiple containers, call and specify the same value for name.
The path specifies the path the volume will be mounted inside the container's file system.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.ContainerResourceBuilderExtensions.WithBindMount``1(Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResourceBuilder{``0},System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Adds a bind mount to a container resource.
member.param: The resource builder.
The source path of the mount. This is the path to the file or directory on the host, relative to the app host project directory.
The target path where the file or directory is mounted in the container.
A flag that indicates if this is a read-only mount.

remarks.para: Bind mounts are used to mount files or directories from the host file-system into the container. If the host doesn't require access to the files, consider using volumes instead via .

The path specifies the path of the file or directory on the host that will be mounted in the container. If the path is not absolute, it will be evaluated relative to the app host project directory path.
The path specifies the path the file or directory will be mounted inside the container's file system.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.ContainerResourceBuilderExtensions.WithContainerRuntimeArgs``1(Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResourceBuilder{``0},System.String[])
member.summary: Adds a callback to be executed with a list of arguments to add to the container runtime run command when a container resource is started.
member.remarks: This is intended to pass additional arguments to the underlying container runtime run command to enable advanced features such as exposing GPUs to the container. To pass runtime arguments to the actual container, use the method.

The arguments to be passed to the container runtime run command when the container resource is started.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.ContainerResourceBuilderExtensions.WithContainerRuntimeArgs``1(Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResourceBuilder{``0},System.Action{Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.ContainerRuntimeArgsCallbackContext})
member.summary: Adds a callback to be executed with a list of arguments to add to the container runtime run command when a container resource is started.
member.remarks: This is intended to pass additional arguments to the underlying container runtime run command to enable advanced features such as exposing GPUs to the container. To pass runtime arguments to the actual container, use the method.
member.param: Builder for the container resource.

A callback that allows for deferred execution for computing arguments. This runs after resources have been allocation by the orchestrator and allows access to other resources to resolve computed data, e.g. connection strings, ports.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.ContainerResourceBuilderExtensions.WithDockerfile``1(Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResourceBuilder{``0},System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Causes .NET Aspire to build the specified container image from a Dockerfile.
member.typeparam: Type parameter specifying any type derived from /
member.param: The .
Path to be used as the context for the container image build.
Override path for the Dockerfile if it is not in the .
The stage representing the image to be published in a multi-stage Dockerfile.

remarks.para: When this method is called an annotation is added to the that specifies the context path and Dockerfile path to be used when building the container image. These details are then used by the orchestrator to build the image before using that image to start the container.
Both the and are relative to the AppHost directory unless they are fully qualified. If the is not provided, the path is assumed to be Dockerfile relative to the .

When generating the manifest for deployment tools, the method results in an additional attribute being added to the `container.v0` resource type which contains the configuration necessary to allow the deployment tool to build the container image prior to deployment.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.ContainerResourceBuilderExtensions.AddDockerfile(Aspire.Hosting.IDistributedApplicationBuilder,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Adds a Dockerfile to the application model that can be treated like a container resource.
member.param: The .
The name of the resource.
Path to be used as the context for the container image build.
Override path for the Dockerfile if it is not in the .
The stage representing the image to be published in a multi-stage Dockerfile.

remarks.para: Both the and are relative to the AppHost directory unless they are fully qualified. If the is not provided, the path is assumed to be Dockerfile relative to the .

When generating the manifest for deployment tools, the method results in an additional attribute being added to the `container.v1` resource type which contains the configuration necessary to allow the deployment tool to build the container image prior to deployment.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.ContainerResourceBuilderExtensions.WithContainerName``1(Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResourceBuilder{``0},System.String)
member.summary: Overrides the default container name for this resource. By default Aspire generates a unique container name based on the resource name and a random postfix (or a postfix based on a hash of the AppHost project path for persistent container resources). This method allows you to override that behavior with a custom name, but could lead to naming conflicts if the specified name is not unique.
member.remarks: Combining this with will allow Aspire to re-use an existing container that was not created by an Aspire AppHost.
member.param: The resource builder for the container resource.
The desired container name. Must be a valid container name or your runtime will report an error.

member.param: The resource builder for the container resource.

The value of the build argument.
member.exception: Thrown when is called before .

remarks.para: The extension method adds an additional build argument the container resource to be used when the image is built. This method must be called after .

member.summary: Adds a secret build argument when the container is built from a Dockerfile.
member.param: The resource builder for the container resource.
The name of the secret build argument.
The resource builder for a parameter resource.
member.exception: Thrown when is called before .

remarks.para: The extension method results in a --secret argument being appended to the docker build or podman build command. This overload results in an environment variable-based secret being passed to the build process. The value of the environment variable is the value of the secret referenced by the .

member.summary: Creates or updates files and/or folders at the destination path in the container.
member.param: The resource builder for the container resource.
The destination (absolute) path in the container.
The file system entries to create.
The default owner UID for the created or updated file system. Defaults to 0 for root if not set.
The default group ID for the created or updated file system. Defaults to 0 for root if not set.
The umask permissions to exclude from the default file and folder permissions. This takes away (rather than granting) default permissions to files and folders without an explicit mode permission set.

remarks.para: For containers with a lifetime, changing the contents of create file entries will result in the container being recreated. Make sure any data being written to containers is idempotent for a given app model configuration. Specifically, be careful not to include any data that will be unique on a per-run basis.

member.summary: Creates or updates files and/or folders at the destination path in the container. Receives a callback that will be invoked when the container is started to allow the files to be created based on other resources in the application model.
member.param: The resource builder for the container resource.
The destination (absolute) path in the container.
The callback that will be invoked when the resource is being created.
The default owner UID for the created or updated file system. Defaults to 0 for root if not set.
The default group ID for the created or updated file system. Defaults to 0 for root if not set.
The umask permissions to exclude from the default file and folder permissions. This takes away (rather than granting) default permissions to files and folders without an explicit mode permission set.

remarks.para: For containers with a lifetime, changing the contents of create file entries will result in the container being recreated. Make sure any data being written to containers is idempotent for a given app model configuration. Specifically, be careful not to include any data that will be unique on a per-run basis.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.ContainerResourceBuilderExtensions.WithContainerFiles``1(Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResourceBuilder{``0},System.String,System.String,System.Nullable{System.Int32},System.Nullable{System.Int32},System.Nullable{System.IO.UnixFileMode})
member.summary: Creates or updates files and/or folders at the destination path in the container by copying them from a source path on the host. In run mode, this will copy the files from the host to the container at runtime, allowing for overriding ownership and permissions in the container. In publish mode, this will create a bind mount to the source path on the host.
member.param: The resource builder for the container resource.
The destination (absolute) path in the container.
The source path on the host to copy files from.
The default owner UID for the created or updated file system. Defaults to 0 for root if not set.
The default group ID for the created or updated file system. Defaults to 0 for root if not set.
The umask permissions to exclude from the default file and folder permissions. This takes away (rather than granting) default permissions to files and folders without an explicit mode permission set.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.ContainerResourceBuilderExtensions.WithEndpointProxySupport``1(Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResourceBuilder{``0},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Set whether a container resource can use proxied endpoints or whether they should be disabled for all endpoints belonging to the container. If set to false, endpoints belonging to the container resource will ignore the configured proxy settings and run proxy-less.
member.param: The resource builder for the container resource.
Should endpoints for the container resource support using a proxy?
member.remarks: This method is intended to support scenarios with persistent lifetime containers where it is desirable for the container to be accessible over the same port whether the Aspire application is running or not. Proxied endpoints bind ports that are only accessible while the Aspire application is running. The user needs to be careful to ensure that container endpoints are using unique ports when disabling proxy support as by default for proxy-less endpoints, Aspire will allocate the internal container port as the host port, which will increase the chance of port conflicts.

member.remarks:

^(?<name>.+?)\\.?AppHost$
Options:
RegexOptions.IgnoreCase | RegexOptions.ExplicitCapture | RegexOptions.Singleline | RegexOptions.CultureInvariant
Explanation:
â—‹ Match if at the beginning of the string.
â—‹ "name" capture group.
â—‹ Match any character lazily at least once.
â—‹ Match '.' atomically, optionally.
â—‹ Match a character in the set [Aa].
â—‹ Match a character in the set [Pp] exactly 2 times.
â—‹ Match a character in the set [Hh].
â—‹ Match a character in the set [Oo].
â—‹ Match a character in the set [Ss].
â—‹ Match a character in the set [Tt].
â—‹ Match if at the end of the string or if before an ending newline.

member.summary: Normalizes the application name for use in physical container resource names (only guaranteed valid as a suffix). Removes the ".AppHost" suffix if present and takes only characters that are valid in resource names. Invalid characters are simply omitted from the name as the result doesn't need to be identical.
member.param: The application name to normalize.
member.returns: The normalized application name with invalid characters removed.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.Dcp.DcpExecutor.GetDcpInstance(Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResource,System.Int32)

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.Dcp.DcpExecutor.NormalizeTargetHost(System.String)
member.summary: Normalize the target host to a tuple of (address, binding mode) to a single valid address for service discovery purposes. A user may have configured an endpoint target host that isn't itself a valid IP address or hostname that can be resolved by other services or clients. For example, 0.0.0.0 is considered to mean that the service should bind to all IPv4 addresses. When the target host indicates that the service should bind to all IPv4 or IPv6 addresses, we instead return "localhost" as the address as that is a valid address for the .NET dev certificate. The binding mode is metdata that indicates whether an endpoint is bound to a single address or some set of multiple addresses on the system.
member.param: The target host from an EndpointAnnotation

member.remarks: A value of zero, which is the default value, indicates that the application will not wait for the container runtime to become healthy. member.name: F:Aspire.Hosting.Dcp.Model.ExecutableState.Unknown
member.summary: Unknown means we are not tracking the actual-state counterpart of the Executable (process or IDE run session). As a result, we do not know whether it already finished, and what is the exit code, if any. This can happen if a controller launches a process and then terminates. When a new controller instance comes online, it may see non-zero ExecutionID Status, but it does not track the corresponding process or IDE session.

member.name: T:Aspire.Hosting.DistributedApplication
member.summary: Represents a distributed application that implements the and interfaces.

remarks.para: The is an implementation of the interface that orchestrates a .NET Aspire application. To build an instance of the class, use the method to create an instance of the interface. Using the interface you can configure the resources that comprise the distributed application and describe the dependencies between them.
Once the distributed application has been defined use the method to create an instance of the class. The class exposes a method which then starts the distributed application and its resources.

The method provides additional options for constructing the including disabling the .NET Aspire dashboard (see ) or allowing unsecured communication between the browser and dashboard, and dashboard and app host (see .

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.DistributedApplication.#ctor(Microsoft.Extensions.Hosting.IHost)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The instance.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.DistributedApplication.CreateBuilder
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the interface.
member.returns: A new instance of the interface.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.DistributedApplication.CreateBuilder(System.String[])
member.summary: Creates a new instance of with the specified command-line arguments.
member.param: The command-line arguments to use when building the distributed application.

remarks.para: The method is the most common way to create an instance of the interface. Typically this method will be called as a top-level statement in the application's entry-point.

Note that the parameter is a and is essential in allowing the application host to work with deployment tools because arguments are used to tell the application host that it is in publish mode. If is not provided the application will not work with deployment tools. It is also possible to provide arguments using the overload of this method.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.DistributedApplication.CreateBuilder(Aspire.Hosting.DistributedApplicationOptions)
member.summary: Creates a new instance of the interface with the specified .
member.param: The to use for configuring the builder.
member.returns: A new instance of the interface.

remarks.para: The method provides greater control over the behavior of the distributed application at runtime. For example providing an argument allows developers to force all container images to be loaded from a specified container registry by using the property, or disabling the dashboard by using the property. Refer to the class for more details on each option that may be provided.
When supplying a custom it is recommended to populate the property to ensure that the app host continues to function correctly when used with deployment tools that need to enable publish mode.

member.name: P:Aspire.Hosting.DistributedApplication.Services
member.summary: Gets the instance configured for the application.

remarks.para: The is an implementation and as such exposes a property which allows developers to get services from the dependency injection container after instance has been built using the method.
To add services to the dependency injection container developers should use the property to access the instance.

member.name: P:Aspire.Hosting.DistributedApplication.ResourceNotifications
member.summary: Gets the service for monitoring and responding to resource state changes in the distributed application.

member.name: P:Aspire.Hosting.DistributedApplication.ResourceCommands
member.summary: Gets the service for executing resource commands.
member.remarks:
Two common use cases for the are:
Progamatically executing resource commands in a running app host.
Unit or integration testing resource commands.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.DistributedApplication.Dispose
member.summary: Disposes the distributed application by disposing the .

remarks.para: Typically developers do not need to worry about calling the Dispose method on the instance because it is typically used in the entry point of the application and all resources used by the application are destroyed when the application exists.

If you are using the and inside unit test code then you should correctly dispose of the instance. This is because the instance initializes configuration providers which make use of file watchers which are a finite resource.

Without disposing of the correctly projects with a large number of functional/integration tests may see a "The configured user limit (128) on the number of inotify instances has been reached, or the per-process limit on the number of open file descriptors has been reached." error.
Refer to the .NET Aspire testing page for more information on how to use .NET Aspire APIs for functional an integrating testing.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.DistributedApplication.DisposeAsync
member.summary: Asynchronously disposes the distributed application by disposing the .

remarks.para: Typically developers do not need to worry about calling the Dispose method on the instance because it is typically used in the entry point of the application and all resources used by the application are destroyed when the application exists.

If you are using the and inside unit test code then you should correctly dispose of the instance. This is because the instance initializes configuration providers which make use of file watchers which are a finite resource.

Without disposing of the correctly projects with a large number of functional/integration tests may see a "The configured user limit (128) on the number of inotify instances has been reached, or the per-process limit on the number of open file descriptors has been reached." error.
Refer to the .NET Aspire testing page for more information on how to use .NET Aspire APIs for functional an integrating testing.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.DistributedApplication.RunAsync(System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Runs an application and returns a Task that only completes when the token is triggered or shutdown is triggered and all instances are stopped.
member.param: The token to trigger shutdown.
member.returns: The that represents the asynchronous operation.

remarks.para: When the .NET Aspire app host is launched via there are two possible modes that it is running in:

list.item: Run mode; in run mode the app host runs until a shutdown of the app is triggered either by the users pressing Ctrl-C, the debugger detaching, or the browser associated with the dashboard being closed.
Publish mode; in publish mode the app host runs just long enough to generate a manifest file that is used by deployment tool.

remarks.para: Developers extending the .NET Aspire application model should consider the lifetime of instances which are added to the dependency injection container. For more information on determining the mode that the app host is running in refer to .

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.DistributedApplication.Run
member.summary: Runs an application and blocks the calling thread until host shutdown is triggered and all instances are stopped.

remarks.para: When the .NET Aspire app host is launched via there are two possible modes that it is running in:

list.item: Run mode; in run mode the app host runs until a shutdown of the app is triggered either by the users pressing Ctrl-C, the debugger detaching, or the browser associated with the dashboard being closed.
Publish mode; in publish mode the app host runs just long enough to generate a manifest file that is used by deployment tool.

remarks.para: Developers extending the .NET Aspire application model should consider the lifetime of instances which are added to the dependency injection container. For more information on determining the mode that the app host is running in refer to .

member.summary: Apply locale from configuration early. At this point it is too early to write to the console so any error from applying the locale is saved to configuration and written once the host is built.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.DistributedApplicationBuilderExtensions.CreateResourceBuilder``1(Aspire.Hosting.IDistributedApplicationBuilder,System.String)
member.summary: Creates a new resource builder based on the name of an existing resource.
member.param: The distributed application builder.
The name of an existing resource.

remarks.para: The method is used to create an for a specific resource where the original resource builder cannot be referenced. This does not create a new resource, but instead returns a resource builder for an existing resource based on its name.

This method is typically used when testing .NET Aspire applications where the original resource builder cannot be referenced directly. Using the method allows for easier mutation of resources within the test scenario.

member.name: T:Aspire.Hosting.ExecutableResourceBuilderExtensions
member.summary: Provides extension methods for adding executable resources to the application model.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.ExecutableResourceBuilderExtensions.AddExecutable(Aspire.Hosting.IDistributedApplicationBuilder,System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String[])
member.summary: Adds an executable resource to the application model.
member.param: The .
The name of the resource.
The executable path. This can be a fully qualified path or a executable to run from the shell/command line.
The working directory of the executable.
The arguments to the executable.
member.remarks:
You can run any executable command using its full path. As a security feature, Aspire doesn't run executable unless the command is located in a path listed in the PATH environment variable.
To run an executable file that's in the current directory, specify the full path or use the relative path ./ to represent the current directory.

member.name: T:Aspire.Hosting.IDistributedApplicationBuilder
member.summary: A builder for creating instances of .

remarks.para: The is the central interface for defining the resources which are orchestrated by the when the app host is launched.

To create an instance of the interface developers should use the method. Once the builder is created extension methods which target the interface can be used to add resources to the distributed application.

example.para: This example shows a distributed application that contains a .NET project (InventoryService) that uses a Redis cache and a PostgreSQL database. The builder is created using the method.
The AddRedis and AddPostgres methods are used to add Redis and PostgreSQL container resources. The results of the methods are stored in variables for later use.

member.summary: Eventing infrastructure for AppHost lifecycle.

member.name: P:Aspire.Hosting.IDistributedApplicationBuilder.ExecutionContext
member.summary: Execution context for this invocation of the AppHost.

remarks.para: The property provides access key information about the context in which the distributed application is running. The most important properties that the provides is the and properties. Developers building .NET Aspire based applications may whish to change the application model depending on whether they are running locally, or whether they are publishing to the cloud.

example.para: An example of using the property on the via the . In this case an extension method is used to generate a stable node name for RabbitMQ for local development runs.

member.summary: Gets the collection of resources for the distributed application.

member.summary: Adds a resource of type to the distributed application.
member.typeparam: The type of resource to add.
member.param: The resource to add.
member.returns: A builder for configuring the added resource.
member.exception: Thrown when a resource with the same name already exists.

remarks.para: The method is not typically used directly by developers building Aspire-based applications. It is typically used by developers building extensions to Aspire and is called from within an extension method to add a custom resource to the application model.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.IDistributedApplicationBuilder.CreateResourceBuilder``1(``0)
member.summary: Creates a new resource builder based on an existing resource.
member.param: An existing resource.

remarks.para: The method is used to create an for a specific resource where the original resource builder cannot be referenced. This does not create a new resource, but instead returns a resource builder for an existing resource.

This method is typically used when building extensions to .NET Aspire where the original resource builder cannot be referenced directly. Using the method allows for easier mutation of resources within the application model.

Calling extension methods on the typically results in modifications to the collection. Not all changes to annotations will be effective depending on what stage of the lifecycle the app host is in. See for more details.

example.para: The following example shows the implementation of the extension method.
The method creates a new in the application model. The return type of is . The type does not implement the .

To work around this issue the method wraps the parameter resource in a "surrogate" class which proxies access to the fields but implements . The method assists by allowing the creation of a without adding another resource to the application model.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.IDistributedApplicationBuilder.Build
member.summary: Builds and returns a new instance. This can only be called once.

remarks.para: Callers of the method should only call it once. are responsible for the lifecycle of the instance that is returned. Note that the type implements and should be disposed of when it is no longer needed. Note that in many templates and samples Dispose is omitted for brevity because in those cases the instance is destroyed when the process exists.

member.name: T:Aspire.Hosting.MissingParameterValueException
member.summary: The exception that is thrown when a parameter resource cannot be initialized because its value is missing or cannot be resolved.
member.remarks:
This exception is typically thrown when:
A parameter value is not provided in configuration and has no default value
A parameter's value callback throws an exception during execution
A parameter's value cannot be retrieved from the configured source (e.g., user secrets, environment variables)

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.OtlpConfigurationExtensions.WithOtlpExporter``1(Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResourceBuilder{``0})
member.summary:
Injects the appropriate environment variables to allow the resource to enable sending telemetry to the dashboard.
It sets the OTLP endpoint to the value of the ASPIRE_DASHBOARD_OTLP_ENDPOINT_URL environment variable.
It sets the service name and instance id to the resource name and UID. Values are injected by the orchestrator.
It sets a small batch schedule delay in development. This reduces the delay that OTLP exporter waits to sends telemetry and makes the dashboard telemetry pages responsive.
member.param: The resource builder.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.OtlpConfigurationExtensions.WithOtlpExporter``1(Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResourceBuilder{``0},Aspire.Hosting.OtlpProtocol)

It sets the service name and instance id to the resource name and UID. Values are injected by the orchestrator.
It sets a small batch schedule delay in development. This reduces the delay that OTLP exporter waits to sends telemetry and makes the dashboard telemetry pages responsive.
member.param: The resource builder.

member.name: T:Aspire.Hosting.ProjectResourceBuilderExtensions
member.summary: Provides extension methods for to add and configure project resources.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.ProjectResourceBuilderExtensions.AddProject``1(Aspire.Hosting.IDistributedApplicationBuilder,System.String)
member.summary: Adds a .NET project to the application model.
member.typeparam: A type that represents the project reference.
member.param: The .
The name of the resource. This name will be used for service discovery when referenced in a dependency.

remarks.para: This overload of the method takes a type parameter. The type parameter is constrained to types that implement the interface.

Classes that implement the interface are generated when a .NET project is added as a reference to the app host project. The generated class contains a property that returns the path to the referenced project file. Using this path .NET Aspire parses the launchSettings.json file to determine which launch profile to use when running the project, and what endpoint configuration to automatically generate.

The name of the automatically generated project metadata type is a normalized version of the project name. Periods, dashes, and spaces in project names are converted to underscores. This normalization may lead to naming conflicts. If a conflict occurs the <ProjectReference /> that references the project can have a AspireProjectMetadataTypeName="..." attribute added to override the name.
Note that endpoints coming from the Kestrel configuration are automatically added to the project. The Kestrel Url and Protocols are used to build the equivalent .

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.ProjectResourceBuilderExtensions.AddProject(Aspire.Hosting.IDistributedApplicationBuilder,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Adds a .NET project to the application model.
member.param: The .
The name of the resource. This name will be used for service discovery when referenced in a dependency.
The path to the project file.

remarks.para: This overload of the method adds a project to the application model using a path to the project file. This allows for projects to be referenced that may not be part of the same solution. If the project path is not an absolute path then it will be computed relative to the app host directory.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.ProjectResourceBuilderExtensions.WithReplicas(Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResourceBuilder{Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.ProjectResource},System.Int32)
member.summary: Configures how many replicas of the project should be created for the project.
member.param: The project resource builder.
The number of replicas.

remarks.para: When this method is applied to a project resource it will configure the app host to start multiple instances of the application based on the specified number of replicas. By default the app host automatically starts a reverse proxy for each process. When is used the reverse proxy will load balance traffic between the replicas.
This capability can be useful when debugging scale out scenarios to ensure state is appropriately managed within a cluster of instances.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.ProjectResourceBuilderExtensions.DisableForwardedHeaders(Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResourceBuilder{Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.ProjectResource})
member.summary: Configures the project to disable forwarded headers when being published.
member.param: The project resource builder.

remarks.para: By default .NET Aspire assumes that .NET applications which expose endpoints should be configured to use forwarded headers. This is because most typical cloud native deployment scenarios involve a reverse proxy which translates an external endpoint hostname to an internal address.
To enable forwarded headers the ASPNETCORE_FORWARDEDHEADERS_ENABLED variable is injected into the project and set to true. If the extension is used this environment variable will not be set.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.ProjectResourceBuilderExtensions.WithEndpointsInEnvironment(Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResourceBuilder{Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.ProjectResource},System.Func{Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.EndpointAnnotation,System.Boolean})
member.summary: Set a filter that determines if environment variables are injected for a given endpoint. By default, all endpoints are included (if this method is not called).
member.param: The project resource builder.
The filter callback that returns true if and only if the endpoint should be included.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.ProjectResourceBuilderExtensions.PublishAsDockerFile``1(Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResourceBuilder{``0},System.Action{Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResourceBuilder{Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.ContainerResource}})
member.summary: Adds support for containerizing this during deployment. The resulting container image is built, and when the optional action is provided, it is used to configure the container resource.
member.remarks: When the executable resource is converted to a container resource, the arguments to the executable are not used. This is because arguments to the project often contain physical paths that are not valid in the container. The container can be set up with the correct arguments using the action.
member.param: Resource builder
Optional action to configure the container resource

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.ResourceBuilderExtensions.WithReference``1(Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResourceBuilder{``0},Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResourceBuilder{Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResourceWithConnectionString},System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Injects a connection string as an environment variable from the source resource into the destination resource, using the source resource's name as the connection string name (if not overridden). The format of the environment variable will be "ConnectionStrings__{sourceResourceName}={connectionString}".
Each resource defines the format of the connection string value. The underlying connection string value can be retrieved using .
Connection strings are also resolved by the configuration system (appSettings.json in the AppHost project, or environment variables). If a connection string is not found on the resource, the configuration system will be queried for a connection string using the resource's name.
member.param: The resource where connection string will be injected.
The resource from which to extract the connection string.
An override of the source resource's name for the connection string. The resulting connection string will be "ConnectionStrings__connectionName" if this is not null.
to allow a missing connection string; to throw an exception if the connection string is not found.
member.exception: Throws an exception if the connection string resolves to null. It can be null if the resource has no connection string, and if the configuration has no connection string for the source resource.

member.summary: Injects service discovery information as environment variables from the project resource into the destination resource, using the source resource's name as the service name. Each endpoint defined on the project resource will be injected using the format "services__{sourceResourceName}__{endpointName}__{endpointIndex}={uriString}".
member.param: The resource where the service discovery information will be injected.
The resource from which to extract service discovery information.

member.summary: Changes an existing endpoint or creates a new endpoint if it doesn't exist and invokes callback to modify the defaults.
member.param: Resource builder for resource with endpoints.
Name of endpoint to change.
Callback that modifies the endpoint.
Create endpoint if it does not exist.

remarks.para: The method allows developers to mutate any aspect of an endpoint annotation. Note that changing one value does not automatically change other values to compatible/consistent values. For example setting the property of the endpoint annotation in the callback will not automatically change the . All values should be set in the callback if the defaults are not acceptable.

member.summary: Exposes an endpoint on a resource. This endpoint reference can be retrieved using . The endpoint name will be the scheme name if not specified.
member.param: The resource builder.
This is the port the resource is listening on. If the endpoint is used for the container, it is the container port.
An optional port. This is the port that will be given to other resource to communicate with this resource.
An optional scheme e.g. (http/https). Defaults to the argument if it is defined or "tcp" otherwise.
An optional name of the endpoint. Defaults to the scheme name if not specified.
An optional name of the environment variable that will be used to inject the . If the target port is null one will be dynamically generated and assigned to the environment variable.
Indicates that this endpoint should be exposed externally at publish time.
Network protocol: TCP or UDP are supported today, others possibly in future.
Specifies if the endpoint will be proxied by DCP. Defaults to true.
member.exception: Throws an exception if an endpoint with the same name already exists on the specified resource.

The callback will be executed after endpoints have been allocated and the URL has been generated.
This allows you to modify the URL or its display text.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.ResourceBuilderExtensions.WaitFor``1(Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResourceBuilder{``0},Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResourceBuilder{Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResource})
member.summary: Waits for the dependency resource to enter the Running state before starting the resource.
member.param: The resource builder for the resource that will be waiting.
The resource builder for the dependency resource.

remarks.para: This method is useful when a resource should wait until another has started running. This can help reduce errors in logs during local development where dependency resources.

Some resources automatically register health checks with the application host container. For these resources, calling also results in the resource being blocked from starting until the health checks associated with the dependency resource return .
The method can be used to associate additional health checks with a resource.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.ResourceBuilderExtensions.WaitFor``1(Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResourceBuilder{``0},Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResourceBuilder{Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResource},Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.WaitBehavior)
member.summary: Waits for the dependency resource to enter the Running state before starting the resource.
member.param: The resource builder for the resource that will be waiting.
The resource builder for the dependency resource.
The wait behavior to use.

remarks.para: This method is useful when a resource should wait until another has started running. This can help reduce errors in logs during local development where dependency resources.

Some resources automatically register health checks with the application host container. For these resources, calling also results in the resource being blocked from starting until the health checks associated with the dependency resource return .
The method can be used to associate additional health checks with a resource.

The parameter can be used to control the behavior of the wait operation. When is specified, the wait operation will continue to wait until the resource becomes healthy. This is the default behavior with the overload.
When is specified, the wait operation will throw a if the resource enters an unavailable state.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.ResourceBuilderExtensions.WaitForStart``1(Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResourceBuilder{``0},Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResourceBuilder{Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResource})
member.summary: Waits for the dependency resource to enter the Running state before starting the resource.
member.param: The resource builder for the resource that will be waiting.
The resource builder for the dependency resource.

remarks.para: This method is useful when a resource should wait until another has started running but doesn't need to wait for health checks to pass. This can help enable initialization scenarios where services need to start before health checks can pass.
Unlike , this method only waits for the dependency resource to enter the Running state and ignores any health check annotations associated with the dependency resource.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.ResourceBuilderExtensions.WaitForStart``1(Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResourceBuilder{``0},Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResourceBuilder{Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResource},Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.WaitBehavior)

remarks.para: This method is useful when a resource should wait until another has started running but doesn't need to wait for health checks to pass. This can help enable initialization scenarios where services need to start before health checks can pass.
Unlike , this method only waits for the dependency resource to enter the Running state and ignores any health check annotations associated with the dependency resource.

The parameter can be used to control the behavior of the wait operation. When is specified, the wait operation will continue to wait until the resource enters the Running state. This is the default behavior with the overload.
When is specified, the wait operation will throw a if the resource enters an unavailable state.

member.summary: Adds a to the resource annotations to add a resource command.

The name of the command. The name uniquely identifies the command.
The display name visible in UI.
A callback that is executed when the command is executed. The callback is run inside the .NET Aspire host. The callback result is used to indicate success or failure in the UI.
Optional configuration for the command.

member.summary: Adds a to the resource annotations to add a resource command.
member.param: The resource builder.
The name of the command. The name uniquely identifies the command.
The display name visible in UI.
A callback that is executed when the command is executed. The callback is run inside the .NET Aspire host. The callback result is used to indicate success or failure in the UI.

param.name: updateState
param.para: A callback that is used to update the command state. The callback is executed when the command's resource snapshot is updated.
If a callback isn't specified, the command is always enabled.

member.param: Optional description of the command, to be shown in the UI. Could be used as a tooltip. May be localized.
Optional parameter that configures the command in some way. Clients must return any value provided by the server when invoking the command.
When a confirmation message is specified, the UI will prompt with an OK/Cancel dialog and the confirmation message before starting the command.
The icon name for the command. The name should be a valid FluentUI icon name from
The icon variant.
A flag indicating whether the command is highlighted in the UI.

remarks.para: The WithCommand method is used to add commands to the resource. Commands are displayed in the dashboard and can be executed by a user using the dashboard UI.
When a command is executed, the callback is called and is run inside the .NET Aspire host.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.ResourceBuilderExtensions.WithHttpCommand``1(Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.IResourceBuilder{``0},System.String,System.String,System.String,System.String,Aspire.Hosting.ApplicationModel.HttpCommandOptions)
member.summary: Adds a command to the resource that when invoked sends an HTTP request to the specified endpoint and path.
member.param: The resource builder.
The path to send the request to when the command is invoked.
The display name visible in UI.
The name of the HTTP endpoint on this resource to send the request to when the command is invoked.
Optional name of the command. The name uniquely identifies the command. If a name isn't specified then it's inferred using the command's endpoint and HTTP method.
Optional configuration for the command.

remarks.para: The command will be added to the resource represented by .

If is specified, the request will be sent to the endpoint with that name on the resource represented by . If an endpoint with that name is not found, or the endpoint with that name is not an HTTP endpoint, an exception will be thrown.

If no is specified, the first HTTP endpoint found on the resource will be used. HTTP endpoints with an https scheme are preferred over those with an http scheme. If no HTTP endpoint is found on the resource, an exception will be thrown.
The command will not be enabled until the endpoint is allocated and the resource the endpoint is associated with is healthy.
If is not specified, POST will be used.
Specifying will use that named when sending the request. This allows you to configure the instance with a specific handler or other options using . If is not specified, the default will be used.
The callback will be invoked to configure the request before it is sent. This can be used to add headers or a request payload before the request is sent.

The callback will be invoked after the response is received to determine the result of the command invocation. If this callback is not specified, the command will be considered succesful if the response status code is in the 2xx range.

member.summary: Class to parse container references (e.g. "mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/sdk:8.0")

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.Utils.ContainerReferenceParser.ImageNameRegex
member.remarks:
Pattern:
^((?<registry>((localhost|\\[(?:[a-fA-F0-9:]+)\\]|([\\w-]+(\\.[\\w-]+)+))(:\\d+)?)|([\\w-]+:\\d+))\\/)?(?<image>[\\w-./<>]+)(:(?<tag>[\\w-.<>]+))?(@(?<digest>.+))?$
Explanation:
â—‹ Match if at the beginning of the string.
â—‹ Optional (greedy).
â—‹ 1st capture group.
â—‹ "registry" capture group.
â—‹ Match with 2 alternative expressions.
â—‹ 2nd capture group.
â—‹ 3rd capture group.
â—‹ Match with 3 alternative expressions.
â—‹ Match the string "localhost".
â—‹ Match a sequence of expressions.
â—‹ Match '['.
â—‹ Match a character in the set [0-:A-Fa-f] atomically at least once.
â—‹ Match ']'.
â—‹ 4th capture group.
â—‹ Match a character in the set [-\w] atomically at least once.
â—‹ Loop greedily at least once.
â—‹ 5th capture group.
â—‹ Match '.'.
â—‹ Match a character in the set [-\w] greedily at least once.
â—‹ Optional (greedy).
â—‹ 6th capture group.
â—‹ Match ':'.
â—‹ Match a Unicode digit atomically at least once.
â—‹ 7th capture group.
â—‹ Match a character in the set [-\w] atomically at least once.
â—‹ Match ':'.
â—‹ Match a Unicode digit atomically at least once.
â—‹ Match '/'.
â—‹ "image" capture group.
â—‹ Match a character in the set [--/<>\w] greedily at least once.
â—‹ Optional (greedy).
â—‹ 8th capture group.
â—‹ Match ':'.
â—‹ "tag" capture group.
â—‹ Match a character in the set [-.<>\w] greedily at least once.
â—‹ Optional (greedy).
â—‹ 9th capture group.
â—‹ Match '@'.
â—‹ "digest" capture group.
â—‹ Match a character other than '\n' greedily at least once.
â—‹ Match if at the end of the string or if before an ending newline.

member.name: M:Aspire.Hosting.Utils.PeriodicRestartAsyncEnumerable.CreateAsync``1(System.Func{System.Nullable{``0},System.Threading.CancellationToken,System.Threading.Tasks.Task{System.Collections.Generic.IAsyncEnumerable{``0}}},System.TimeSpan,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Creates an async enumerable that wraps and periodically restarts an inner async enumeration. This is intended to keep long running watch enumerations fresh and will recreate the watch enumeration on a set interval or if the inner enumerable terminates unexpectedly. The goal is to ensure that we keep the wrapped enumeration active until the main token is cancelled.
member.typeparam: The type the enumerable iterates over
member.param: Factory method that takes the last iterrated value (if one exists) and a and returns a fresh to enumerate over
How often should we get a new enumerable from the factory
Stop all enumeration once this is cancelled
member.returns: An of items returned by the inner iterables

member.name: M:Aspire.ChannelExtensions.GetBatchesAsync``1(System.Threading.Channels.Channel{``0},System.Nullable{System.TimeSpan},System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Reads batches, grabbing all available messages and returning them as one batch before yielding. This can give a better downstream experience, as there's less per-item overhead.
member.remarks: This sequence adopts the lifetime of . Callers are required to either use a channel that will complete, or to pass a cancellation token which will also cancel the sequence returned by this method.
member.typeparam: The type of items in the channel and returned batch.
member.param: The channel to read values from.
The minimum read interval. The enumerable will wait this long before returning the next available result.
A token that signals a loss of interest in the operation.

member.name: M:Aspire.Dashboard.ConsoleLogs.TimestampParser.GenerateRfc3339RegEx
member.remarks:
Pattern:
^ # Starts the string\r\n(\\d{4}) # Four digits for the year\r\n- # Separator for the date\r\n(0[1-9]|1[0-2]) # Two digits for the month, restricted to 01-12\r\n- # Separator for the date\r\n(0[1-9]|[12][0-9]|3[01]) # Two digits for the day, restricted to 01-31\r\nT # Literal, separator between date and time, either a T or a space\r\n([01][0-9]|2[0-3]) # Two digits for the hour, restricted to 00-23\r\n: # Separator for the time\r\n([0-5][0-9]) # Two digits for the minutes, restricted to 00-59\r\n: # Separator for the time\r\n([0-5][0-9]) # Two digits for the seconds, restricted to 00-59\r\n(\\.\\d{1,9})? # A period and up to nine digits for the partial seconds (optional)\r\n(Z|([Z+-]([01][0-9]|2[0-3]):([0-5][0-9])))? # Time Zone offset, in the form Z or ZHH:MM or +HH:MM or -HH:MM (optional)
Options:
RegexOptions.ExplicitCapture | RegexOptions.IgnorePatternWhitespace | RegexOptions.CultureInvariant
Explanation:
â—‹ Match if at the beginning of the string.
â—‹ Match a Unicode digit exactly 4 times.
â—‹ Match '-'.
â—‹ Match with 2 alternative expressions.
â—‹ Match a sequence of expressions.
â—‹ Match '0'.
â—‹ Match a character in the set [1-9].
â—‹ Match a sequence of expressions.
â—‹ Match '1'.
â—‹ Match a character in the set [0-2].
â—‹ Match '-'.
â—‹ Match with 3 alternative expressions.
â—‹ Match a sequence of expressions.
â—‹ Match '0'.
â—‹ Match a character in the set [1-9].
â—‹ Match a sequence of expressions.
â—‹ Match a character in the set [12].
â—‹ Match a character in the set [0-9].
â—‹ Match a sequence of expressions.
â—‹ Match '3'.
â—‹ Match a character in the set [01].
â—‹ Match 'T'.
â—‹ Match with 2 alternative expressions.
â—‹ Match a sequence of expressions.
â—‹ Match a character in the set [01].
â—‹ Match a character in the set [0-9].
â—‹ Match a sequence of expressions.
â—‹ Match '2'.
â—‹ Match a character in the set [0-3].
â—‹ Match ':'.
â—‹ Match a character in the set [0-5].
â—‹ Match a character in the set [0-9].
â—‹ Match ':'.
â—‹ Match a character in the set [0-5].
â—‹ Match a character in the set [0-9].
â—‹ Optional (greedy).
â—‹ Match '.'.
â—‹ Match a Unicode digit greedily at least 1 and at most 9 times.
â—‹ Optional (greedy).
â—‹ Match with 2 alternative expressions, atomically.
â—‹ Match 'Z'.
â—‹ Match a sequence of expressions.
â—‹ Match a character in the set [+-Z].
â—‹ Match with 2 alternative expressions.
â—‹ Match a sequence of expressions.
â—‹ Match a character in the set [01].
â—‹ Match a character in the set [0-9].
â—‹ Match a sequence of expressions.
â—‹ Match '2'.
â—‹ Match a character in the set [0-3].
â—‹ Match ':'.
â—‹ Match a character in the set [0-5].
â—‹ Match a character in the set [0-9].

member.name: M:Aspire.IConfigurationExtensions.GetValueWithNormalizedKey(Microsoft.Extensions.Configuration.IConfiguration,System.String)
member.summary: Gets a configuration value with support for dash-to-underscore normalization. First tries the exact configuration key, then tries with dashes replaced by underscores.

member.returns: The configuration value, or if not found.
